title: Floods and heavy rainfall
summary: Stronger storms are bringing flash floods to towns and farms across Uganda.
content: Uganda has seen more intense rainfall events that overwhelm drainage systems and riverbanks. Floods can damage homes, wash away crops, and increase water-borne diseases. Planning for safer housing, early warnings, and better land management helps reduce risks.
keyImpacts: Damage to homes, bridges, and roads
Higher risk of cholera and malaria outbreaks
studentActions: Keep school drainage clear and report blocked channels
Create awareness posters about flood safety
Join tree-planting days in your community
localExamples: Bududa and Mbale districts have experienced landslides after heavy rains
Flooding around Lake Kyoga has displaced families

title: Drought and water scarcity
summary: Long dry spells stress crops, livestock, and household water supplies.
content: Droughts reduce river flow and groundwater recharge, leaving communities with less water for farming and daily use. Climate-smart irrigation, water harvesting, and drought-tolerant crops can improve resilience.
keyImpacts: Lower crop yields and food shortages
studentActions: Practice water-saving habits at home and school
Help build simple rainwater harvesting systems
Share lessons about drought-tolerant crops
localExamples: Karamoja communities often face severe water shortages
Cattle keepers in Nakapiripirit move longer distances for pasture

title: Rising temperatures
summary: Hotter days and nights affect health, learning, and energy demand.
content: Temperature increases can lead to heat stress, lower productivity, and higher energy use for cooling. Schools and households can stay cooler with shade trees, ventilation, and smart building design.
keyImpacts: Heat stress for children and outdoor workers
studentActions: Plant shade trees around classrooms
Encourage light-colored roofs to reflect heat
Stay hydrated and share heat safety tips
localExamples: Kampala records hotter temperatures in densely built neighborhoods
Northern Uganda often experiences high heat during dry seasons

title: Climate-smart agriculture
summary: Uganda’s farmers are adapting planting times and crops to new climate patterns.
content: Agriculture employs many Ugandans, yet changing rainfall and heat threaten yields. Climate-smart techniques like mulching, agroforestry, and improved seed varieties help farmers protect soils and stabilize harvests.
keyImpacts: Crop pests spreading to new areas
studentActions: Learn about agroforestry and share at school clubs
Start a small school garden using mulch
Support local farmers’ markets
localExamples: Coffee farmers in Mukono are shifting to shade-grown varieties
Bean farmers in Kabale use terraces to stop erosion

title: Health and climate
summary: Climate change affects disease patterns and access to clean air and water.
content: Warmer temperatures and floods can increase malaria and water-borne diseases. Communities need clean water, good sanitation, and health education to prevent outbreaks.
keyImpacts: Higher cases of malaria and dengue
Respiratory problems from smoke and dust
studentActions: Promote mosquito net use
Join clean-up campaigns to reduce stagnant water
Share health tips through school radio or clubs
localExamples: Floods in eastern Uganda have led to cholera outbreaks
Dusty dry seasons in Gulu affect respiratory health

title: Lake Victoria and fisheries
summary: Changing weather affects fish stocks and lakeside livelihoods.
content: Lake Victoria supports fishing and transport for millions. Warmer waters and storms disrupt fish breeding and make fishing riskier. Sustainable fishing and shoreline protection are essential.
keyImpacts: More dangerous storms on the lake
studentActions: Learn about sustainable fishing rules
Support shoreline clean-up initiatives
Reduce plastic waste that ends up in the lake
localExamples: Entebbe fish markets report fluctuating fish supplies
Kalangala islands face shoreline erosion

title: Deforestation
summary: Forest loss reduces rainfall regulation and wildlife habitat.
content: Trees store carbon and stabilize climate. When forests are cleared for fuel or farmland, Uganda loses biodiversity and natural water regulation. Replanting and sustainable wood use are critical.
studentActions: Join school tree nurseries
Use energy-saving stoves at home
Learn about protected forests
localExamples: Mabira Forest has faced illegal logging pressures
Queen Elizabeth National Park protects critical habitats

title: Urban heat and city growth
summary: Growing cities like Kampala trap heat and create hotter neighborhoods.
content: Concrete, traffic, and fewer trees raise temperatures in cities. Urban planning that includes green spaces, shade, and public transport can cool cities and improve air quality.
studentActions: Advocate for more trees in school surroundings
Use public transport, biking, or walking
Participate in city clean-up activities
localExamples: Kampala’s central business district records higher heat
New green spaces in Jinja help cool neighborhoods

title: Waste burning and air pollution
summary: Open burning releases harmful smoke and greenhouse gases.
content: Many communities burn waste due to limited collection services. Smoke affects health and adds to climate warming. Sorting waste, recycling, and composting reduce pollution.
studentActions: Start a waste sorting corner at school
Encourage composting of food scraps
Promote community clean-up days
localExamples: Kiteezi landfill in Kampala faces waste management challenges
Plastic waste has affected drainage in Wakiso

title: Clean energy transition
summary: Renewable energy can reduce emissions and improve access to power.
content: Uganda is expanding solar, hydropower, and efficient cookstoves. Clean energy lowers air pollution and supports economic growth while reducing greenhouse gases.
keyImpacts: Reduced air pollution from charcoal and firewood
More reliable power for schools and clinics
studentActions: Learn about solar energy in science clubs
Switch off unused lights and devices
Support clean cookstove projects
localExamples: Solar mini-grids serve communities in rural Uganda
Bujagali Hydropower supports national electricity supply
